message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Paralysis of the right lower lip is a common complication of surgery involving the parotid gland. This is due to the facial nerve running through the gland and being at risk of damage during surgery. Hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe and hyperacusis of the right ear are both unlikely complications of parotid gland surgery. Impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue may occur, but it is less common than lip paralysis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The parotid gland is responsible for innervating the facial nerve, specifically the branches responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation  for the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, and saliva secretion to the mouth. Damage to the facial nerve during the procedure can lead to the paralysis of the right lower lip. Hyperacusis of the right ear is not related to the parotid gland, and hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe and impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue are not directly related to the facial nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The parotid gland is located near the facial nerve, which controls the muscles of the face. During surgery to remove a tumor in the parotid gland, there is a risk of injuring the facial nerve and causing paralysis of the right lower lip. This is a common and expected complication associated with parotidectomy. Options A, B, and D are not directly related to the location of the parotid gland or the risk of surgery in this area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The parotid gland is innervated by the facial nerve, which can be damaged during surgery and lead to paralysis of the right lower lip. Hyperesthesia of the ear lobe and hyperacusis of the ear are not consistent with the anatomy of the facial nerve, and impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue are associated with damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve, not the facial nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A total parotidectomy involves removal of the parotid gland, which contains the facial nerve. Paralysis of the right lower lip is a common complication due to damage to the mandibular branch of the facial nerve during surgery. Hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe (A) and hyperacusis of the right ear (B) are less common complications, as they are associated with damage to the auriculotemporal nerve. Impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue (D) is also less likely, as the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve, which is responsible for taste sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue, is usually preserved during total parotidectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A total parotidectomy involves removal of the facial nerve that runs through the parotid gland and can cause right lower lip paralysis. Hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe and hyperacusis of the right ear are less likely to occur, and impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue are associated with glossopharyngeal nerve damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is diagnosed with parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma, and total parotidectomy is scheduled. During the surgery, the facial nerve that innervates the lower lip may be affected, leading to paralysis of the right lower lip. This is a known early complication of the surgery. The other options are not directly related to the surgery or the affected area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The planned surgery for parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma may cause damage to the facial nerve, which can cause paralysis of the right lower lip. The other options are not common early complications of this surgery. Hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe may occur due to damage to the posterior auricular nerve, but it is not a common complication. Hyperacusis of the right ear and impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue may occur due to damage to the chorda tympani nerve, but this nerve is not typically involved in this type of surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The parotid gland is located near the facial nerve, which controls the muscles of the face. During surgery to remove the gland, damage to this nerve can occur, resulting in paralysis of the lower lip. Hyperesthesia and hyperacusis are not common complications of parotidectomy, and impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue are more likely to occur with surgery involving the tongue or taste buds.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The surgery involves the parotid gland, which is supplied by the facial nerve. Paralysis of the right lower lip is a common early complication due to damage to the facial nerve during the surgery. Hyperesthesia of the ear lobe and hyperacusis are less likely as they are not directly related to the surgery site. Impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue is also less likely as the lesion is in the parotid gland, not affecting the tongue.
